title: Flyknit
description: Analyzing "high-tech" Nike shoe, reverse engineering and making our own version on low-tech mechanical machines
author: Elise Co, Martin Bernard, Keda Jiang
researchQuestions: Can we replicate a "high-tech" shoe using "low-tech" manual knitting machines?
What are the knit structures that make up Nike Flyknit technology?

title: AI Knits
description: We use traditional 2-color knitting patterns (repeating motifs) to generate new patterns. Custom software to preview and curate/select the "good" patterns
author: Elise Co, Ying Huang
researchQuestions: What if we generate knitting patterns using AI?

title: Dioramas
description:
These self-contained interactives provide virtual spaces in which to play with our digital materials. The only interaction is to click to switch the material applied to a particular surface. Browsing and curation become acts of creative production.

Each diorama explores the formal parameters of digital "space": 
scale(lessness)
true 2D (zero-thickness plane)
simulation of physical world vs abstraction
author: Elise Co, Nanyi Jiang, Miaoqiong Huang, Qi Tan, Christie Wu
researchQuestions: What is our digital material applied to?
What's the relationship between the material and the form/object it forms?
What are formal parameters of digital "space"?

title: The Material Loop
description:
We define material as: anything that can be shaped or formed into something else.

The line between  object (or content) and material is sometimes just a matter of quantity. In a world of digital copy-and-paste and  algorithmic generation, anything and everything is material.
author: Elise Co, Martin Bernard, Mavis Cao, Isabelle Chaligne, Christie Wu
researchQuestions: Can anything become a material? How?
What are the implications of producing material vs something "finished"?

title: Sample Swatchbook
description:
A sample book is a catalog of textile samples, or swatches, usually a small rectangular piece of the textile accompanied by description. The description varies according to the purpose of the sample book, and may include: pricing; technical specifications; performance characteristics; structural details. Sample books are also formally analogous to stitch libraries found in how-to textile hobby books; in those cases, the descriptions are usually instructions or patterns for replicating the swatch.

Sample Swatchbook is the design of a swatchbook template for the samples made in SAMPLER 1. Initially intended to frame the swatches as technical materials, in the process of designing and using the templates the team expanded their framing not just as documentation of a swatch, but also: the process of making the swatch; iterations of a particular swatch; and the identification of "analagous materials" to help support ideation around them as materials.
author: Elise Co, Ray Cao, Mina Lee, Fei Wang, Meredith Xu
researchQuestions: What’s the difference between "technical materials" and home-produced knitting swatches?
How can we frame "hobby knitting" as technical material research?

title: Fractal Knits
description: Making our own knitting machines to make knits out of other knits: Level1, Level2, etc. Recursive/fractal structures. Concentration of labor.
author: Elise Co, Ray Cao, Yuwen Lin, An Pan, Meredith Xu
researchQuestions: What’s the difference between "technical materials" and home-produced knitting swatches?
How can we frame "hobby knitting" as technical material research?

title: SAMPLER 1
description: SAMPLER 1, initially just SAMPLER, was an MDP Summer Research project for 2019. SAMPLER centered around mechanical knitting machines, but explored a variety of formal and conceptual questions. The SAMPLER ethos of trying lots of different smaller things, and then synthesizing, was first tested in research group format here.
author: Elise Co, Martin Bernard, Rei Cao, Ying Huang, Keda Jiang, Mina Lee, Yuwen Lin, An Pan, Fei Wang, Meredith Xu
